title: Show HN: Toy Wallet – A virtual bank for playing Monopoly with NFC support
text:
Hey HN,

Yesterday I finally released my first App on the AppStore :)

It all began when we played Monopoly with a few friends and started running out of paper money quite often. I always loved the idea of the banking version of Monopoly (with the chip cards) so I decided to develop something similar as an app.

You can create multiple accounts (everyone can pick his favourite colour), and then transfer money to each other or to/from the bank.

To prevent cheaters you can also either set a PIN for each account that has to be entered whenever money is being taken out or (if your device supports it) use a NFC (NTAG) card or token as authorization method.

We really love using the app in our family especially when playing it with NFC cards as it gives a real banking feeling :)

You can also start multiple games and pick up a game later if you need to interrupt playing.

I translated the app in as many languages possible but I guess there might be a lot of translation mistakes :)

I'm really looking forward to get some feedback from you folks on the app, what do you think I could improve? And please feel free to share any translaton mistake you have found.

- Max

title: Resources to Learn Software Development
Ask HN: What it takes to build Jarvis using current state of the art LLMs?
text:
For people who don't know Jarvis, it's a know-it-all personal assistant which just doesn't answer but also perform actions based on commands. It's catered to specific person needs. We want this to run on your preferred device instead of cloud

I thought we were miles away from building something like this because of so many complex parts involved

1. State of the art speech to text generation ( Shout out to Whisper here )

2. State of the art question answering ( GPT-*, LLama, etc..)

3. Integration with your virtual life ( emails, music, finances etc..)

1 & 2 have definitely shown significant progress. the major bottle neck right now is 3. Most of our virtual life is centralised and no one provides a clean API such that we can actually have a holistic view of everyone's digital persona in one place. And last but not least, privacy and security is super important considering we are giving the total access to a bot. Am I missing anything else? Would like to see some healthy discussion on this topic

Ask HN: How did my GitHub password breach and how to react?
text:
I got a 2 way authentication warning from github that someone in canada successfully entered my github password and was stopped by 2 way authentication.

Normally session warnings are business as usual but in this case my password was entered and it was generated by a password manager with high entropy, was only stored in dashlane, 1password and chrome password manager.

A google search for the password had no results and have haveibeenpwned shows no known breach. I have no idea how this could have leaked and what my security status is now. I have some productivity apps on my mac with accessibility permissions to read my clipboard (yippy, zoom, teams, pgp), but i am not sure i have to assume one of these apps is compromised and wipe my whole machine.

Does anyone have any ideas about breaches not in haveibeenpwned or what a reasonable response would be or could chime in what they would do? I know in theory i would need to wipe my machine and then change all my passwords wich would take weeks, but i am not sure this is an overreaction.
